entry.title: Europe‚Äôs iconic train route faces fresh competition
entry.summary:
London St Pancras Highspeed (LSPH), the company responsible for the London station and the high-speed track to Folkestone, has drawn up plans to triple capacity at the notoriously congested station. Several train companies are vying to run services across the channel, adding new routes to the continent and ending Eurostar‚Äôs monopoly.
This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Passengers travelling to Europe by rail could see a raft of new train operators in the coming years. Eurostar ‚Äî which has always had a monopoly on services between London and Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam ‚Äî now faces the biggest threat of competition since it launched its first train through the Channel Tunnel in 1994. With the promise of more choice and lower prices, could this be ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 of the best wild swimming spots in the UK
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs no better way to immerse yourself in nature than by going wild swimming. Every spot tells its own story: tidal pools fed by Scottish mountains leave your skin humming; river estuaries in Cornwall carry the scent of salt and oak; and in London, ponds are hangouts for locals looking to escape the city streets. Here, we round up seven of the most scenic, whether you‚Äôre looking for somewhere to go with your family or a wild adventure. They‚Äôre as beautiful as they are grounding, so take your time. And don‚Äôt forget to bring a flask; one of the best things about cold water is warming up again.
Set at the foot of the Black Cuillin mountains, a 20-minute walk from the Glenbrittle car park, these tumbling pools loo‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to experience northern Somerset without a Glastonbury ticket
entry.summary:
Glastonbury Tor has scenic steps with views over the Somerset Levels and into the neighbouring counties of Wiltshire and Dorset. The legendary music festival is just one reason to visit an area many are calling ‚Äòthe new Cotswolds‚Äô ‚Äì a hotbed of rural creativity home to some of the UK‚Äôs finest food.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
For decades, Somerset was chiefly famous for three things ‚Äî cider, cheddar cheese and ‚Äòscrumpy and western‚Äô band The Wurzels, whose musical homage to the combine harvester landed them a 1976 number one. Glastonbury Festival‚Äôs rise to prominence gradually shifted the dial on the county‚Äôs profile ‚Äî taking it from agricultural to alternative and, latterly, decidedly cool. Those who visit today will find it a delightful ‚Ä¶

ËÆ© AI ÂéªÂà§Êñ≠Âì™‰∫õÂú∞ÊñπÈúÄË¶ÅÂèÇËÄÉÊñáÁåÆÁÑ∂ÂêéËá™Âä®ÂéªÊü•ÊâæÂíåÊ∑ªÂä†ÔºåËøôÊ†∑Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•Ëß£ÂÜ≥Ëøô‰∏™È¢òÁõÆÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ ÊØîÂ¶ÇÂú® Claude ÁöÑ Desktop ÁâàÊú¨Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂÖàÂÆâË£ÖÂ•Ω„ÄÇ claude npx -y @smithery/cli@latest install @JackKuo666/pubmed-mcp-server --client claude --config "{}" ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂÜçÁî®Ëøô‰∏™‰ª£Á†ÅÊù•ÈÖçÁΩÆÂ•Ω„ÄÇ { "mcpServers": { "Google-Scholar": { "command": "bash", "args": [ "-c", "source /home/YOUR/PATH/.venv/bin/activate && python /home/YOUR/PATH/Google-Scholar-mcp-server.py" ], "env": {}, "disabled": false, "autoApprove": [] } } }

entry.title: The 8 best Little Italy neighborhoods in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Dubbed an "elevated beer hall,‚Äù Nolita in San Diego‚Äôs Little Italy neighborhood features an on-site restaurant that serves a menu of woodfired pizzas and shareable plates, a large lounge area with various seating options, and a 24-tap horseshoe-shaped bar that also serves a menu of wine and craft cocktails. From Boston‚Äôs North End to San Francisco‚Äôs North Beach, these communities are still serving the country's most authentic, tastiest Italian food.
Frank DePasquale was a teenager in 1955 when his family left the foot of Mount Vesuvius in Naples to immigrate to Boston‚Äôs North End. His father was chasing the Italian dream of expanding his company Ambrosio, now one of the world‚Äôs biggest Italian confetti candy (Jordan almond) suppliers. Sadly, he passed away shortly after they arrive‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside San Diego‚Äôs secret to happiness
entry.summary:
In a vibrant Manhattan venue transformed to mirror San Diego‚Äôs warmth and energy, the film, Portraits of San Diego: A Culture of Happiness, unveiled what makes this southern California 'beach city' a beacon of optimism. The event on May 19, hosted at Chelsea's Lavan 541, drew an exclusive audience including VIP guests, travel and lifestyle media, editors, prominent social media influencers, and valued travel industry partners‚Äîall immersed in an authentic San Diego experience blending innovative culinary delights, stunning imagery by National Geographic photographer Kiliii Y√ºyan, and insightful conversations.
The evening opened with Chef Tara Monsod‚Äôs inspired menu, celebrating San Diego‚Äôs multicultural heritage and coastal freshness. Dishes like the "Point Loma Ponzu" and "La Jolla Lo‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the potato went from banned to beloved
entry.summary:
The potato‚Äôs journey from despised and feared to dinner-table staple reveals how this simple root reshaped economies and cultures. Potatoes were once so despised they were linked to leprosy. What changed? It's a tale of propaganda, survival, and ordinary people‚Äôs resilience.
This history of the potato, like the spud itself, has been baked into folklore, mashed into politics, and fried into a thousand origin myths. However, the tuber‚Äôs rise to global stardom wasn‚Äôt a simple matter of hunger meets harvest‚Äîit was a slow-cooked saga of stigma, spin, and sheer necessity.
What started as sacred Indigenous knowledge of the potato was swiftly rebranded as salvation. Monarchs, scientists, and opportunistic propagandists all took turns serving the spud as miracle, menace, or national m‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this Spanish city became the holy grail of pilgrimages
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Some cheer, some clap, some clasp each other‚Äôs shoulders in quiet ecstasy. One lets his walking stick fall to the ground, one kicks her walking boots off, another stretches his sore back and sighs. But most sit on the cobbled square and lean back, resting on backpacks stuffed like pillows. In front of them, the cathedral‚Äôs western towers reach heavenwards, and seem even taller from this low angle. With no farther left to walk, the pilgrims lie and stare.
‚ÄúLying in the Praza do Obradoiro at the end of the Camino de Santiago is a tradition,‚Äù says guide Maria Guerra Gomez of 1 2 Tours, her halo of black curls bouncing with her nods as we watch pilgrims take in their first sight of the square‚Äôs imposing cathedral. We‚Äôr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Say ciao to these alcohol-free takes on Italian aperitivo classics
entry.summary:
Italy‚Äôs evolving bar scene caters increasingly to sober-minded consumers with non-alcoholic alternatives found at most cafes. There‚Äôs culture, there‚Äôs tradition‚Äîand then there‚Äôs drinks. From Italy‚Äôs historical north to the tip of the boot, options abound for alcohol-free enjoyment of the famed aperitivo.
Between 6 and 8 p.m. each evening, bars and cafes across Italy buzz. For Italians, the tradition of aperitivo represents less a happy hour and more a state of mind. This golden hour that beautifully separates work from free time offers friends and family a chance to gather over cocktails and conversation.¬†
The word for aperitivo comes from the Latin aperire, which means to open, in reference to opening digestion before dinner. Its medicinal purpose dates back to ancient R‚Ä¶

entry.title: China is building the world‚Äôs largest national parks system
entry.summary:
Six-month-old pandas eat snacks at the China Conservation and Research Center for Giant Panda Dujiangyan Base in Dujiangyan, China. Within the next decade, China hopes to become a global leader in protected nature reserves, creating a network of wilderness that would be three times the size of the U.S. system.
China plans to overtake the United States by building the world‚Äôs largest national park system, a network of wilderness bigger than Texas. Although China only created its first¬†national park four years ago‚Äîsome 149 years after the US did the same‚Äîit claims that by 2035 it will have 49 parks covering 272 million acres, triple the size of the U.S. National Park System.
China has already opened five national parks, totaling 57 million acres. Collectively, the parks span alp‚Ä¶

entry.title: Shaping a better world at Expo 2025 in Japan
entry.summary: How can we build a fairer, more peaceful world while safeguarding the planet? That‚Äôs the powerful question at the heart of the United Nations Pavilion at Expo 2025 in Osaka, Japan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council meets in emergency session over Iran-Israel conflict, amid strikes and counterstrikes
entry.summary: Israel‚Äôs strikes on Iranian nuclear and military facilities mark a dangerous new escalation in the Middle East, a top UN official told the Security Council during an emergency session convened on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Societies grappling with a ‚Äòsilent but growing‚Äô prison crisis
entry.summary: Prisons have become a fragile link in many criminal justice systems, weakened by over-incarceration, overcrowding, poor conditions and chronic neglect ‚Äì fuelling calls for urgent reform.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Rights abuses in Haiti, Sudan war sees exodus to Chad, food trade optimism
entry.summary: Escalating gang violence in Haiti has displaced a record 1.3 million people, UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarians must be able to deliver aid in Gaza, UN agencies insist
entry.summary: UN agencies on Friday continue to stress they must be allowed to deliver aid in the Gaza Strip as famine looms and a telecommunications blackout threatens lifesaving operations.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN ocean summit in Nice closes with wave of commitments
entry.summary: Ships in the port of Nice sounded their fog-horns on Friday, a brassy crescendo to a rare moment of global unity as the Third UN Ocean Conference drew to a close. Moments earlier, more than 170 countries had adopted by consensus a sweeping political declaration promising urgent action to protect the ocean.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: Aid teams appeal for support to help displaced communities left with nothing
entry.summary: As diplomatic efforts continue to end fighting in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the UN development agency (UNDP) issued an appeal on Friday on behalf of people uprooted by the violence to help them rebuild their lives and livelihoods.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel-Iran crisis: UN chief urges calm after overnight strikes
entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres condemned Israeli strikes in Iran late Thursday evening, urging ‚Äòmaximum restraint‚Äô from Member States. The head of the UN-backed atomic watchdog also highlighted the risk of a wider conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New ‚Äòdragon prince‚Äô dinosaur is missing ancestor of T. Rex
entry.summary: This illustration depicts how the slender Khankhuuluu mongoliensis may have appeared as it roamed Mongolia during the Cretaceous period. The newest addition to the tyrannosaur family, the discovery of this "dragon prince from Mongolia" sheds light on the origins of Tyrannosaurus rex. Khankhuuluu mongoliensis was slender with features like no other member of the tyrannosaur family tree. Tyrannosaurus rex is a carnivorous icon. Exceeding 40 feet in length and nine tons, the bone-crushing giant stands out as the largest and last of its meat-eating family. Now a new and far smaller tyrannosaur is filling in the famous dinosaur‚Äôs evolutionary b‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Alexander the Great's daddy issues reshaped the world
entry.summary:
Alexander the Great‚Äôs childhood has often been presented as a time of conflict between his parents, Philip II and Olympias. But this image, so often explored in novels and films, is likely exaggerated. Most of the sources preserved from this period are Athenian; no Macedonian writings have survived. So it was Philip‚Äôs enemies, with their subjective and even manipulated accounts, who shaped what we know about the intricacies of the Macedonian court. Nevertheless, dynastic tensions evidently ran high at the court of Philip, and one factor that had an impact on family relations was the practice of polygamy.
Marriage in Macedonia was a politically oriented institution, often used to establish diplomatic relations or ensure royal succession. Philip had seven wives but among them they bore ‚Ä¶

entry.title: A traveler‚Äôs guide to the east side of Vancouver Island
entry.summary:
The east side of Vancouver Island is ideal for adventurous travelers, with mountains, forests, oceans, and rivers. From world-class whale watching to oysters shucked at their source, there is a fascinating mix of culture, wildlife, and cuisine on the eastern coastline of British Columbia‚Äôs largest island.
When people think about Vancouver Island‚Äîthe largest island on North America‚Äôs west coast and just 60 miles west of Vancouver‚Äîthey may picture the cosmopolitan capital of Victoria in the South Island, or perhaps its ancient forests, home to some of the tallest trees on Earth. But the island‚Äôs eastern coastline, from Nanaimo up to Port Hardy, offers a glimpse into an even quieter way of life, where you can stroll one of the windswept beaches, go on a world-class whale watching expe‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the foundry forging $15,000 artisanal samurai swords
entry.summary: At Nippon Genshosha, a sword workshop on Japan‚Äôs Tango Peninsula, Tomoyuki Miyagi (left), Tomoki Kuromoto (center), and Kosuke Yamazoe (right) work together to hammer, heat, and fold a piece of steel. The process, called tanren, strengthens the metal. It can take more than a year to make a single razor-sharp katana. In Japan, business is booming for the few remaining smiths who know how to do it. In a converted barn¬†on a residential lane on Japan‚Äôs Tango Peninsula, some 75 miles north of Kyoto, three men are playing with fire. While robust flames lick the edges of a 2300-degree furnace, Kosuke Yamazoe uses a 15-pound hammer on a mass of white-hot steel, flattening it beat by beat in a hypnotic rhythm. Behind the shower of embers raining down on the earthen floor, Tomoyu‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Basque city is known for pintxos‚Äîand it's not San Sebastian
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sitting at the smart, horseshoe bar of El Tolo√±o, veteran head chef Josu Armi√±o is letting me into a secret. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got something that I think other places don‚Äôt have, and that‚Äôs the simplicity of the way we use ingredients,‚Äù he says, sporting pristine chef‚Äôs whites and a slightly mischievous smile. ‚ÄúFor me, the most important thing is the quality of the produce we have here.‚Äù
In the Basque capital of Vitoria-Gasteiz, El Tolo√±o is one of the most locally revered pintxos bars ‚Äî and for good reason. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about creating things with foams and all that,‚Äù Josu goes on to explain. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about simplicity and building on the traditions of our grandparents‚Äô cooking,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWe add a touch of glamour and a bit more wa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Your breathing pattern is unique like your fingerprint
entry.summary:
Colored 3D computed tomography (CT) scan of the spaces within the facial bones surrounding the nasal cavity. In a new study, scientists identified people based only on their breathing pattern with almost 97 percent accuracy‚Äîand soon might be able to analyze yours to diagnose what ails you.
Everyone‚Äôs breathing pattern is unique, and soon scientists might be able to analyze yours to diagnose what ails you.
Scientists were able to identify individual people based just on their breathing pattern with 96.8 percent accuracy, and different patterns corresponded to differences in physical and mental traits, according to a new study in Current Biology.
Because it happens subconsciously, breathing may seem simple, but it‚Äôs controlled by a complex brain network.¬†
‚ÄúRespiration ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Free Asha. Or cage her?
entry.summary:
Asha is circling the perimeter of her pen. She‚Äôs pacing, moving with that long, rangy gait that all Mexican gray wolves have, her body graceful and liquid, motions smooth and purposeful. She stalks around jagged rocks, behind juniper bushes and yucca plants. She runs from the humans in her pen, anxious and hyperaware. For my part, I‚Äôm awestruck. This is the closest I‚Äôve been to a wolf, and I‚Äôm only able to see her because she is currently being held in captivity by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) in the Sevilleta Wolf Management Facility near Socorro, New Mexico.
Asha has been ensnared; and like so many humans invested in her, so have I.¬†
The four-year-old she-wolf has been placed in the facility because she refuses to stay put, repeatedly crossing into territory off‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to find the perfect gelato in Rome
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
There‚Äôs never a wrong time for gelato in Rome. But nothing beats the sensation of cooling down with a deliciously fresh scoop on a hot summer day. With hundreds of gelaterie (ice cream parlours) across the Eternal City, the challenge isn‚Äôt finding gelato, it‚Äôs finding the best one. But what, exactly, is gelato?
This is one of the most common questions people ask when visiting Rome, and while both ice cream and gelato are beloved frozen treats, the difference between the two lies in the ingredients, texture and how they‚Äôre served. Gelato contains more milk and less cream than ice cream, resulting in a lower fat content, which some people find easier to digest. It‚Äôs churned at a slower speed, incorporating less air, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 160 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Jan. 8-19, 2025, among a sample of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) U.S. adults. A total of [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: The Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report was made possible with support from the Trusts and from the People & Voices Initiative. ¬† This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/gender-lgbtq. [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Rising Number of U.S. Households Are Headed by Married Same-Sex Couples
entry.summary: The number of households headed by same-sex couples in the U.S. has risen steadily, but they represent a small share of all married couples. The post Rising Number of U.S. Households Are Headed by Married Same-Sex Couples appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Same-Sex Parents Raising Kids
entry.summary: Same-sex parents discuss their unique challenges and paths to parenthood, as well the support they've received from their families, friends and communities. The post Same-Sex Parents Raising Kids appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: UN General Assembly adopts Gaza ceasefire resolution by overwhelming majority
entry.summary: Meeting in emergency session on Thursday in New York, the UN General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution demanding an immediate, unconditional and lasting ceasefire in Gaza.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: ‚ÄòIndifference and impunity‚Äô in Sudan, ICC judges speak out against sanctions, respiratory diseases overlooked in Europe
entry.summary: With over half of the Sudanese population in need of aid and lean season rapidly approaching, the¬†UN Chief for Humanitarian Affairs once again¬†sounded the alarm about the crisis unfolding in Sudan on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief ‚Äòdeeply saddened‚Äô as Air India crash claims lives of over 200 on board
entry.summary: A London-bound Air India jet carrying 242 people crashed moments after take-off from Ahmedabad on Thursday, reportedly killing more than 200 on board, with dozens still unaccounted for.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen at breaking point as UN envoy urges action to end suffering
entry.summary: Yemen cannot endure more years of division, economic collapse and human suffering, the UN‚Äôs top official on the crisis told the Security Council on Thursday, warning that ‚Äútime is not on our side.‚Äù

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Famine stalks two counties in South Sudan as fragile peace is threatened
entry.summary: Two counties in the Upper Nile State of South Sudan are sliding into famine, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) warned in a new report released Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòNo Ocean Declaration without small islands‚Äô: Delegates push for inclusion as UN summit nears end
entry.summary: With one day remaining before the conclusion of the Third UN Ocean Conference, delegates in Nice are preparing for the adoption of the summit‚Äôs eagerly anticipated political declaration. Small island developing States, facing the direct effects of climate change and marine resource decline, are pushing to ensure their perspectives are reflected in global ocean policy.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global push to end plastic pollution gains ground in Nice
entry.summary: Behind closed doors, in a domed conference pavilion steps away from the historic port of Nice, more than 40 ministers gathered on Tuesday to tackle one of the planet‚Äôs fastest-growing environmental threats: plastic pollution.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Decades of memories and loss ‚Äì searching for the missing in Syria
entry.summary: Tens of thousands of people went missing in Syria over the past 50 years including during 14 years of civil war. Now, some families are able to live in hope as the Middle Eastern country emerges from the traumatic period of dictatorship and conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: UN General Assembly to vote on resolution demanding immediate, unconditional and permanent ceasefire
entry.summary: The General Assembly meets at 3pm in New York on Thursday in emergency session following the Security Council‚Äôs failure to adopt a resolution on 4 June calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, which was vetoed by permanent member the United States. As starvation looms across the Strip, mass casualties continue to be reported of desperate civilians trying to access food at Israel and US-backed distribution sites. App users can follow our live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Atomic watchdog says Iran not complying with nuclear safeguards
entry.summary: The UN-backed atomic watchdog voted through a resolution on Thursday declaring that Iran is not complying with its obligations regarding nuclear non-proliferation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Displacement doubles while funding shrinks, warns UNHCR
entry.summary: With 13.5 million people displaced by over 13 years of brutal civil conflict, Syria used to represent the largest displacement crisis in the world. This is no longer the case.

entry.title: Investigating Mexico: An Interview with the Reporter, Writer, and Film-Maker Diego Enrique Osorno

entry.title: These U.S. national sites honor the milestones of LGBTQ+ heritage
entry.summary:
In the Greenwich Village neighborhood of New York City, the Gay Liberation Monument in Christopher Park near the Stonewall Inn pays homage to the historically pivotal Stonewall Rebellion, which included prominent gay rights activists including Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera. See the country‚Äôs past through a distinctly queer lens at these National Park Service-managed destinations.
Just as it turned 100 in 2016, America‚Äôs National Park Service (NPS) began to officially recognize the contributions that LGBTQ+ Americans have made to the rich and diverse history of the United States.
Given the groundbreaking importance of New York City‚Äôs Stonewall Inn to global queer history, the National Park Service (NPS) ¬†fittingly named New York City‚Äôs Stonewall National Monument as its f‚Ä¶

entry.title: Not everyone should be taking a multivitamin
entry.summary:
Though multivitamins provide a tempting solution, the best way to get the nutrients your body needs is through good food, like broccoli. In some situations, they can be helpful. In others, they can lead to dangerous nutrient deficiencies or imbalances. Experts weigh in on how to make an informed decision.
Do multivitamins ensure your body gets everything it needs? It's a complicated question without a one-size-fits-all answer.
While there‚Äôs no doubt taking multivitamins may benefit some people, experts suggest assessing your nutritional needs before popping a daily multivitamin.
‚ÄúA large amount of vitamins can cause nausea, vomiting, dehydration, confusion, and organ damage, such as [to the] liver or kidney,‚Äù says medical oncologist Liudmila Schafer. ‚ÄúAdditionally, multiv‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 hotels that offer a taste of 'quiet luxury'
entry.summary:
Mollie, a hotel in Aspen, uses earthy tones, ceramics, hand-dyed fabrics, and natural textures in its 68 rooms and suites. This cultural and design trend is all about understated elegance. You can indulge on the road, too, in these eight hotels that offer everything from perfectly weighted linens to zoned lighting and heated floors.
In recent years, quiet luxury‚Äîa trend of pared-back elegance driven by cultural phenomenon and social media influencers‚Äîtook over fashion. The same ethos has been guiding travelers to certain hotels.
‚ÄúQuiet luxury¬†is about spaces that feel effortlessly refined, where everything has been carefully considered but nothing screams for attention,‚Äù says Pamela Schein Murphy, founder of Wandrist Travel. She notes that details like the texture and weight o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here's why Friday the 13th scares us
entry.summary:
Scholars believe the superstition around Friday the 13th may have roots in religious beliefs‚Äîbut most research has shown that the day isn't any more unlucky than other days on the calendar.

Find out how the date got its unlucky reputation and how even nonbelievers may be influenced by our collective triskaidekaphobia. The creepiest day on the calendar has returned: Friday the 13th. In 2023, there were two ill-fated Fridays, one in January and another in October. In 2024, we saw two again, in September and December. This year, we're back to one, on June 13. But it seems that no matter how many of these frightening Fridays we survive unharmed, the dreaded day continues to inspire unease and fears of misfortune. There‚Äôs no logical reason to fear the occasional co‚Ä¶

entry.title: A new children‚Äôs book celebrates our amazing origins in Africa
entry.summary:
You‚Äôve probably heard that we can all trace our roots back to Africa. It‚Äôs a fact that most people learn about briefly in a history class or find out through 23andMe. Still, this shared origin story often feels like a blip in our consciousness compared to other time periods. It‚Äôs a commonality we‚Äôre willing to acknowledge but not always explore.¬†¬†
Picture-book author and film illustrator Nikkolas Smith fills in this curiosity gap with his latest book, The History of We, which he both wrote and illustrated. The self-described ‚Äúartivist‚Äù has dedicated much of his career to rendering crucial moments and people in Black history through expressive paintings, from portraits of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor to a comic-book treatment of the Obamas. One of his most well-known projects is The‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 of the best summer festivals to travel to, according to an expert
entry.summary:
One of the most famous Midsummer celebrations is found in the central Swedish town of Leksand. Festivals, when cultures reveals themselves most vividly, are some of the best times to visit a new destination ‚Äî here are the six best summer festivals to travel to this summer.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
There‚Äôs no better time to visit a new place than during a festival. These heightened moments, special points in the calendar, are when a culture reveals itself most vividly: town squares are festooned with flowers and draped in finery, people conceal themselves beneath extravagant costumes and wild-eyed masks, and the air is filled with the sound of music and the delicious smells of festival food.
But beyond just being outwardly captivat‚Ä¶

entry.title: The secret to early animal sketches? Butterfly dust
entry.summary: Jan van Kessel the Elder. Noah‚Äôs Family Assembling Animals Before the Ark, c. 1660 oil on panel. A first-ever collaboration between the National Gallery of Art and the Smithsonian examines the birth of natural history. The National Gallery of Art and the Smithsonian‚Äôs Natural History Museum have been next-door neighbors in Washington, DC for nearly 90 years‚Äîbut until now, they‚Äôve never shared so much as a cup of coffee across the fence. That all changes this summer, as the two institutions collaborate to create a cross-pollinated art and natural science exhibition featuring selections from the art gallery‚Äôs centuries-old paintings of birds, bugs, and exotic critters ‚Ä¶ along with actual examples of those creatures drawn from the Smithsonian‚Äôs enormous collection of anim‚Ä¶

entry.title: Vera Rubin was the GOAT of dark matter
entry.summary:
Astronomer Vera Rubin spent much of her career at the Carnegie Institution‚Äôs Department of Terrestrial Magnetism in Washington, D.C. She's best known for convincing the world that dark matter exists. How the pioneering scientist, and namesake of an enormous new telescope, forced astronomers to rethink the universe.
Vera Rubin had just finished her ice cream when she saw something that would change astronomy forever. It was long past midnight one early morning in the 1960s, and Rubin and her colleague Kent Ford were at Kitt Peak National Observatory in the middle of the Arizona desert. That night they were tracking how hot gas from young stars circled Andromeda, the Milky Way‚Äôs galactic neighbor. Rubin and Ford would trade off recording the gases‚Äô chemical fingerprints or processin‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Richard Wike, Director, Global Attitudes ResearchJacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchLaura Silver, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchJanell Fetterolf, Senior Researcher Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix C: Detailed charts, Trump‚Äôs characteristics
entry.summary: The post Appendix C: Detailed charts, Trump‚Äôs characteristics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Classifying European political parties
entry.summary: Classifying parties as populist Although experts generally agree that populist political leaders or parties display high levels of anti-elitism, definitions of populism vary. We use three measures to classify populist parties: anti-elite ratings from the 2019 Chapel Hill Expert Survey (CHES), Norris‚Äô Global Party Survey and The PopuList. We define a party as populist when [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix B: Classifying European political parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline
entry.summary: There were many events, meetings and announcements that occurred shortly before and during our fieldwork period that may have impacted how people in other countries perceive the U.S. and its president. We highlight a few prominent events here that were relevant across multiple countries and directly relate to the questions included in our survey. The post Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Comparing confidence in Trump, Macron, Putin and Xi
entry.summary: Macron receives the highest ratings across the 24 countries surveyed, followed by Trump, but views of these two leaders diverge sharply in several nations. The post 5. Comparing confidence in Trump, Macron, Putin and Xi appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Views of Trump‚Äôs characteristics
entry.summary: Majorities in many countries surveyed describe Trump as arrogant, dangerous and a strong leader. Relatively few see him as well-qualified to be president, diplomatic or honest. The post 4. Views of Trump‚Äôs characteristics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Confidence in Trump to handle global issues
entry.summary: On balance, most people across 24 nations are not confident in Trump to handle immigration, conflict in Ukraine and Israel, China relations, the global economy, and climate change. The post 3. Confidence in Trump to handle global issues appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Confidence in Trump
entry.summary: Across 24 nations, a median of 34% have confidence in Trump, while 62% do not. Trump receives lower ratings than Biden did in many countries surveyed. The post 2. Confidence in Trump appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of the United States
entry.summary: Across 24 nations, a 49% median view the U.S. favorably, while an identical share do not. People are also roughly split on whether U.S. democracy works well. The post 1. Views of the United States appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Gang violence displaces a record 1.3 million Haitians
entry.summary: Nearly 1.3 million people have been forced to flee gang violence in Haiti and seek refuge elsewhere within the Caribbean country, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) said Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Rising hunger in Gaza highlights urgent need for ‚Äòunfettered‚Äô aid supplies
entry.summary: People in the Gaza Strip are getting hungrier because of the ‚Äúvery limited‚Äù volume of food being allowed in, UN aid agencies reiterated on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: Ongoing Russian strikes continue alarming civilian casualty trend
entry.summary: Civilian deaths and injuries in the first five months of 2025 were nearly 50 per cent higher than the same period last year, UN rights experts tasked with monitoring abuses in war-torn Ukraine said on Wednesday in their latest¬†report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate emergency is a health crisis ‚Äòthat is already killing us,‚Äô says WHO
entry.summary: With 2024 confirmed as the hottest year on record, the World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a stark warning: the climate crisis is also a health crisis ‚Äì and it‚Äôs already claiming lives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòPlenty of fish in the sea‚Äô? Not anymore, say UN experts in Nice
entry.summary: At the Third UN Ocean Conference in Nice, the ‚Äúcatch of the day‚Äù wasn‚Äôt a seabass or a red mullet ‚Äì it was a figure: 35 per cent. That‚Äôs the share of global fish stocks now being harvested unsustainably, according to a new UN report released Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The world pledged to end child labour by 2025: So why are 138 million kids still working?
entry.summary: 12-year-old Tenasoa crawls to work every day at a mine in eastern Madagascar where she collects two kilos of the shiny mineral mica each day. She cannot walk because of a physical disability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At least eight die in Red Sea tragedy as smugglers force migrants overboard
entry.summary: Survivors of a people-smuggling operation gone wrong in the Red Sea have recounted how they were forced off their boat far from the coast of Djibouti and left to swim for their lives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: RJ Andrews and Attila B√°torfy highlight information graphics from Signal, the Nazi propaganda‚Ä¶ Tags: Attila Batorfy, Nazi, propaganda, RJ Andrews

entry.title: Climate Change Reporting and Mental Health: Practical Tips for Newsrooms and Journalists
entry.summary: The Reuters Institute presents a webinar discussing the latest research into the impact of climate reporting on journalists' mental health.

entry.title: Do dogs need people to survive? The truth might hurt.
entry.summary:
A group of dogs greets their human family on a farm. A miniature dachshund survived in the wild for 529 days. Could your dog? Experts say it depends on these traits.
In late April, a miniature dachshund named Valerie was found healthy and alert on Kangaroo Island, just off the coast of Adelaide, Australia‚Äîafter she had been missing for 529 days.¬†¬†
Surprisingly, Valerie, who had become separated from her family during a vacation to the island in November 2023, had even gained about four pounds in the wild.
‚ÄúShe went out as a skinny little sausage dog and came back as a rippling mass of muscle,‚Äù says¬†Jared Karran, a director at the nonprofit¬†Kangala Wildlife Rescue, who released¬†footage¬†of Valerie‚Äôs rescue. ‚ÄúJust the healthiest dog you'd ever want to see‚Äîperfect teeth, per‚Ä¶

entry.title: Love Sicily but not the crowds? Visit this island instead
entry.summary:
Pollara, located on the northwest side of Salina, was created by a partially collapsed volcanic crater. Just a boat ride from Sicily, the island of Salina offers an authentic, laid-back Italian getaway with volcanic cliffs, lush landscapes, and extraordinary views.
Hop on a hydrofoil from Milazzo, Sicily, and in less than two hours you‚Äôll find yourself on the beautiful island of Salina. Stromboli's volcano stands tall on the distant horizon, and unlike Sicily, there are not many crowds of people. Locals whizz by on mopeds while only a few tourists relax at a sea cove on the side of the road.
Salina is the second-largest island in the Aeolian archipelago (Lipari is the largest), yet it is home to only around 2,500 residents, making the island the perfect immersion into relaxed ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 200 years ago, tourists flocked to Paris‚Äîto see corpses
entry.summary:
This mid-1800s illustration shows how the Paris Morgue put unidentified bodies on public display‚Äîdrawing crowds of curious onlookers behind the glass. Before true crime and reality TV, there was the Paris Morgue‚Äîwhere crowds queued to see the dead. It was the first of its kind, and for decades, the city‚Äôs strangest attraction.
In 1870s Paris, expensive plate glass panes meant one of two things: high-end shopping or public spectacle. At la Morgue de Paris, it meant both.
Inside, the city‚Äôs unclaimed dead lay on tilted marble slabs beneath a trickle of water meant to stave off decay. While some still wore the clothes they were found in, most were naked, with only leather loincloths placed over their genitals. Other garments‚Äîcoats, boots, even umbrellas‚Äîwere hung above or beside ‚Ä¶

entry.title: From Stonehenge to Sedona, why are we drawn to mystical places?
entry.summary:
Places like Stonehenge, Machu Picchu, and the Borobudur Temple can stir up deep emotional responses in the human brain, scientists and researchers say. Sacred sites have long lured travelers seeking a connection to something bigger. In a world grappling with digital overload, these pilgrimages are on the rise.
As the sun rises at Chaco Canyon, shadows stretch across ancient sandstone with such precise astronomical alignment that it‚Äôs easy to believe it was designed for a cosmic purpose. At Machu Picchu, the intricate stonework and mountaintop design reveal feats of engineering that leave visitors in quiet reverence. Sedona‚Äôs red rocks hum with rumored energy vortexes. On the Salisbury Plain, Stonehenge casts shadows both on the landscape and on its original purpose.¬†
Across th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Video: How much ‚Äòreligious switching‚Äô is there in the U.S.?
entry.summary: 35% of U.S. adults no longer identify with the religion in which they were raised ‚Äì that's about 90 million people who have changed their religious identities. The post Video: How much ‚Äòreligious switching‚Äô is there in the U.S.? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology

entry.title: The Political Gap in Americans‚Äô News Sources
entry.summary: Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to both use and trust many major news sources, according to Pew Research Center. The post The Political Gap in Americans‚Äô News Sources appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: She's inspiring a new future for Africa‚Äôs nomadic herders
entry.summary:
Long before European powers carved up West Africa and independent African states inherited their contemporary borders, a great nomadic tradition began‚Äîone that continues and evolves today. Around November, as the rainy season ends and the southern fringes of the Sahara desert begin to dry and brown again, hundreds of thousands of Fulani herders gather to drive millions of cattle, goats, and sheep toward cooler subtropical savannas.
This annual movement has made the Fulani one of the largest nomadic groups on Earth, but it has also helped exclude them from politics: Despite their large numbers, the transient herders are less likely to be counted by states. An added obstacle to representation is the fact that many of the region‚Äôs governments are more invested in farming than herding. Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists are solving the mystery of how axolotls regrow limbs
entry.summary:
When a sharp shrub severs a salamander tail or it loses an arm in a predator fight, the animal sits back and waits. Within weeks, the missing body part regrows good as new.¬†
For years scientists have wondered how these amphibians work this magic, and whether humans might one day follow suit. A study published June 10th in Nature Communications takes a giant step in understanding the phenomenon, detailing the biology by which axolotls regrow the exact missing limb in its proper place.
Retinoic acid, a substance also abundant in the human body‚Äîas well as in many skin creams‚Äîhas long been known to be a major player. Now it‚Äôs clear that a particular enzyme (which humans have too) finely tunes levels of the retinoid at the animal‚Äôs wound site to ensure the correct part appears. At the‚Ä¶

entry.title: Love whisky? Here's where to try it in Scotland
entry.summary:
The red-brick, riverside buildings that make up Deanston Distillery were in fact an 18th-century cotton mill, before they were converted to whisky-making in 1966. Whether you‚Äôre a single-malt connoisseur or whisky newbie, a distillery pilgrimage should be part of every Scottish trip.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Pagoda chimneys rising above pine-forested glens, the babble of a highland spring, the distinctive aroma of toasted malt ‚Äî distilleries are far more than functional factories. Often set in spectacular settings, they‚Äôre crucibles of living, breathing Scottish heritage. And many invite visitors inside to view bubbling mash tuns, gleaming copper stills and warehouses filled with oak barrels, revealing the almost alchemical process tha‚Ä¶

entry.title: We've never seen this rare squid alive in the wild‚Äîuntil now
entry.summary: In the frigid waters near Antarctica, the elusive squid Gonatus antarcticus was recently spotted by a remotely operated vehicle. It's the first time this squid has been seen alive. In the deep seas found at the Earth‚Äôs poles, explorers are still finding elusive and mysterious sea creatures. On an expedition in the Southern Ocean, researchers captured stunning video of the Antarctic gonate squid for the first time. Reporting in this article is presented by the National Geographic Society in partnership with Rolex under the National Geographic and Rolex Perpetual Planet Ocean Expeditions. It was late on Christmas Eve and the frigid waters of the Southern Ocean's Weddell Sea weren't cooperating.¬†¬† The scientists and crew onboard the Schmidt Ocean Institute‚Äôs ship R.‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can Africa‚Äôs great nomadic people save their way of life?
entry.summary:
Near the southern edge¬†of the Sahara desert, millions of people in some 20 West and Central African countries share a way of life. Year after year, they take part in the ancient practice of nomadic pastoralism, herding livestock across increasingly hot, arid lands of the Sahel region in search of fresh grasslands¬†and accessible water as the seasons change. From the western coast of Senegal to the eastern shorelines of Sudan, herders follow different migratory routes that can cover hundreds of miles. ¬†
Most of these pastoralists share another important distinction: They are Fulani, an Indigenous people who have a broad cultural identity shaped by such traditional journeys. These groups are vast and varied, and many are traveling in new directions. https://interactives.natgeofe.com‚Ä¶

entry.title: World News in Brief: Global growth slows, deadly Ukraine attacks, Haiti hurricane hunger risk, legal migration for refugees
entry.summary: Global economic growth is expected to decline this year due to increased trade barriers and policy uncertainty, the World Bank said in a report published on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar on the ‚Äòpath to self-destruction‚Äô if violence does not end
entry.summary: Nearly three months after a catastrophic earthquake struck Myanmar, the country continues to grapple with its aftermath alongside the brutal civil war which has devastated the country since the February 2021 military coup.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global action needed as progress stalls on disability-inclusive development goals
entry.summary: Nearly all the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) indicators for persons with disabilities are off track the UN deputy chief said on Tuesday, as people from around the world gathered for the largest annual meeting on disability-related issues.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN committed to supporting ‚Äòfree, fair and transparent election with the participation of all Iraqis‚Äô
entry.summary: The top UN official in Iraq reiterated his confidence in the resilience of the country‚Äôs people, and the determination of their leaders, in a briefing to the Security Council on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The battle to quiet the sea: Can the shipping industry turn down the volume?
entry.summary: The ocean has never been silent ‚Äì waves crashing, seabirds calling, whales singing across vast distances. But in recent decades, a new kind of noise has taken hold: the relentless hum of ships. For many marine species, this growing wall of sound is more than a nuisance ‚Äì it‚Äôs a threat to their survival.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israeli attacks on Gaza schools could be crimes against humanity: UN probe
entry.summary: The Israeli military‚Äôs destruction of Gaza‚Äôs education and cultural infrastructure amount to war crimes and the crime against humanity of extermination, a UN investigative body said on Tuesday, as humanitarian agencies warned of continued mass suffering across the Strip.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Greed is driving oceans toward collapse
entry.summary: The ocean is under siege ‚Äì and greed is to blame. UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres on Tuesday urged world leaders and grassroots groups alike to confront the powerful interests driving marine destruction, from illegal fishing and plastic pollution to the accelerating impacts of climate change.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan emergency: We need more help to prevent famine, says WFP
entry.summary: The very real risk of famine continues to stalk Sudan‚Äôs communities impacted by war, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Tuesday, in an appeal for more funding to support immediate needs and boost longer-term recovery across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Social and economic barriers, not choice, driving global fertility crisis: UNFPA
entry.summary: The global fertility slump isn‚Äôt down to young people turning their backs on parenthood ‚Äì it‚Äôs due to social and economic pressures stopping them from having the children they want, says a new UN report.

entry.title: What is Ethiopian philosophy?
entry.summary: Riven by two competing schools of thought, the future of philosophical enquiry in Ethiopia stands at a crossroads - by Fasil Merawi Read at Aeon

entry.title: Flower blooms to visualize climate change
entry.summary: Annelie Berner used blooming flowers as a visual metaphor to show climate change.‚Ä¶ Tags: Annelie Berner, climate change, flower

entry.title: Europe‚Äôs city tours are better than ever‚Äîhere‚Äôs where to go
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There was a time when a perfunctory potter round the key sites with a dusty guide serviced by an even dustier script was the summit of our city-tour ambitions. Now, driven by a new breed of innovative and passionate advocates eager to exalt their home towns, the choice is boundless. Whether you‚Äôre looking to scratch the surface of a destination or really get under its skin, you won‚Äôt struggle to find a tour as unique, compelling and fun as the guides who lead them. Here, we celebrate a selection of the latter ‚Äî from a retired policeman on a very different beat in London to a Barcelona ‚Äòsightjogger‚Äô and a kayaker offering an unusual take on the City of Bridges.
Visitors to Venice have been getting out on the water‚Ä¶

entry.title: Jellyfish are finally giving up their secrets
entry.summary:
A pair of sea butterflies (Corolla spectabilis) drift just beneath the surface. Though they might not look like it, these are actually snails that have evolved wings to live in the water column. Scientists are unraveling the mysteries of the ocean‚Äôs squishiest creatures‚Äîincluding one jelly that might be the oldest animal species on Earth.
Gelatinous zooplankton, colloquially known as jellies, are an evolutionary hodge-podge of squishy, translucent creatures composed mostly of water. While this group does include ‚Äútrue jellyfish‚Äù with their iconic rounded bell and stinging tentacles, it is also host to a smattering of creatures such as worms, primitive chordates, and snails with wings.
‚ÄúIf being 95 percent water is what unites the group, that is where it ends,‚Äù says Grace C‚Ä¶

entry.title: A giant mass of seaweed threatens beach season in the U.S.
entry.summary:
The Great Atlantic Sargassum Belt‚Äîa goopy mass of leafy, floating seaweed stretching across 5,000 miles‚Äîis slated to be a nuisance of record breaking proportions this year. In May, scientists at the University of South Florida observed over 37 million metric tons of sargassum in the Caribbean Sea, Atlantic Ocean, and Gulf of Mexico.
Later this month, the seaweed will continue washing ashore on Caribbean and U.S. beaches.
In the past decade it's increasingly become a problem for beachgoers and seaside businesses‚Äîand a rotting, smelly one at that‚Äîbut sargassum is a natural part of the ocean food chain.
‚ÄúIn the vast expanse of the ocean, it can be an oasis,‚Äù says Brian Barnes, a marine scientist at the University of South Florida. The patches of seaweed can be a home and source‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 stunning UNESCO sites that were immortalized on screen
entry.summary: A local Jordanian Bedouin leads his camels through the desert to Wadi Rum, a UNESCO World Heritage Site featured in movies such as Dune, Lawrence of Arabia, The Martian, and Star Wars films. From the "Tomb Raider Temple" to Dune's alien landscapes, these iconic destinations captured the attention of early set-jetters. In 1989, the appearance of Petra‚Äôs ancient tomb known as the Treasury [Al-Khazneh] in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade electrified moviegoers. Following the film‚Äôs release, annual attendance at Jordan‚Äôs formerly obscure UNESCO World Heritage Site skyrocketed‚Äîreaching nearly a million visitors by 2010. Today, the link between the haunting, rock-faced tombs and the Hollywood blockbuster continues to capture the attention of set‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This section describes the methods used to estimate religious composition at the country level, regionally and globally; our procedures for measuring religious groups‚Äô demographic characteristics and their religious ‚Äúswitching‚Äù rates; as well as methodological challenges that we considered in some countries. The final section lists the 201 countries and territories that make up each of [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report was produced by Pew Research Center as part of the Pew-Templeton Global Religious Futures project, which analyzes religious change and its impact on societies around the world. Funding for the Global Religious Futures project comes from The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John Templeton Foundation (grant 62287). Find related reports online at¬†https://www.pewresearch.org/globalreligiousfutures. This [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 14. Religion in sub-Saharan Africa
entry.summary: Most people in sub-Saharan Africa are Christian. Christians and Muslims grew rapidly in number in the region from 2010 to 2020. The post 14. Religion in sub-Saharan Africa appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 13. Religion in North America
entry.summary: A majority of North Americans are Christian. But Christian populations declined in the U.S. and Canada, while the unaffiliated grew, from 2010 to 2020. The post 13. Religion in North America appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 12. Religion in the Middle East and North Africa
entry.summary: Every religious group grew in count in the Middle East and North Africa ‚Äì a Muslim-majority region ‚Äì between 2010 and 2020. The post 12. Religion in the Middle East and North Africa appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 11. Religion in Latin America and the Caribbean
entry.summary: Most people in the Latin America-Caribbean region are Christian. The region's unaffiliated population grew rapidly since 2010. The post 11. Religion in Latin America and the Caribbean appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 10. Religion in Europe
entry.summary: Christians are still a majority in Europe but disaffiliation thinned the Christian population from 2010 to 2020. The post 10. Religion in Europe appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9. Religion in Asia and the Pacific
entry.summary: Hindus, Muslims and the unaffiliated each make up about a quarter or more of the Asia-Pacific population. These groups all grew there from 2010-2020. The post 9. Religion in Asia and the Pacific appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 8. Jewish population change
entry.summary: Jewish people make up 0.2% of the world population. Jews rose in number by 6% from 2010 to 2020, mostly due to growth in Israel. The post 8. Jewish population change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 7. ‚ÄòOther religions‚Äô population change
entry.summary: Baha‚Äôis, Jains, Sikhs, Daoists and other groups that Pew Research Center classified as "other religions" combined ‚Äì grew globally by 12% from 2010 to 2020. The post 7. ‚ÄòOther religions‚Äô population change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How to plan an epic road trip through Baja California
entry.summary:
Many travelers complete this route in two weeks, but the more time you have, the better. This is the perfect route to discover the magic of Mexico‚Äôs Baja peninsula, from its pristine beaches to charming historic towns and unspoiled landscapes.
Mexico was made for road trips. Its landscapes are diverse, breathtaking, and adventure-packed, as well as filled with cultural experiences and mouthwatering cuisine. My husband and I have driven over 10,000 miles across Mexico in our RV, and while we‚Äôve loved our year-and-a-half trip, one route stood out above the rest: the Baja California peninsula.
Jutting off from California and wedged between the Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California, the Baja California peninsula is the ultimate road trip for adventure seekers. The journey down ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to drink in Jerez, the birthplace of Spanish sherry
entry.summary:
El Pasaje is the town‚Äôs oldest tabanco, or sherry bar. In the midst of a revival, Spain‚Äôs famed fortified wine is best sampled at the source ‚Äî in the whitewashed Andalucian town of Jerez de la Frontera, where locals bond in bodegas and bars.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A pretty place with a jumble of Moorish-style courtyards, gothic churches and grand baroque buildings, the small Andalucian city of Jerez is largely untouched by gentrification and tourism ‚Äî despite being only an hour from Seville. Yet it has a long-held reputation as the country‚Äôs sherry capital: ‚Äòjerez‚Äô means ‚Äòsherry‚Äô in Spanish and the fortified wine has been made here for over 3,000 years.
Once considered old fashioned, sherry has stepped back into the spotlight i‚Ä¶

entry.title: 5 vineyard restaurants to visit in England
entry.summary:
Hambledon Vineyard's award-winning sparkling wines include the classic cuvee and, new for 2025, its first blanc de blancs. England‚Äôs top wineries are increasingly pairing their vintages with smart dishes that draw on the best local produce.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the UK‚Äôs dynamic wine scene, seasonally led vineyard restaurants are becoming as much of a draw as the wine itself, ideal for languid summer afternoons. Here are five of the best to whet your appetite ‚Äî from Michelin-starred venues getting creative with locally foraged ingredients to an East Sussex hotspot where wood-wired pizzas are paired with the perfect natural wine.
Operating since 1952, Hambledon is the UK‚Äôs oldest commercial winery. Its award-winning sparkl‚Ä¶

entry.title: What dinosaur has 500 teeth? This ancient jaw was one-of-a-kind
entry.summary:
What dinosaur has 500 teeth and replaced each and every one of them every 14 days? With 15 times more teeth than the human set of 32,¬†Nigersaurus taqueti hacked through low-lying vegetation with choppers like a lawn mower, paleontologist and National Geographic Explorer Paul Sereno told National Geographic¬†just years after he and colleagues first described and named the dinosaur.¬†
About as heavy as an adult¬†African forest elephant, this dinosaur would have weighed about two tons and stretched about 30 feet long from nose to the tip of its tail. The herbivore wandered lowlands of western Africa about 105 million years ago in what‚Äôs now the Republic of Niger.
Nigersaurus¬†was one of the most effective plant-eating creatures to have ever evolved. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about¬†Ni‚Ä¶

entry.title: These 6 European cities are synonymous with music
entry.summary:
The House of Strauss is the world‚Äôs only remaining concert hall where all four Strausses performed. Whether an old folk ballad or a futuristic techno hit, music is the lifeblood of Europe‚Äôs great cities and one of the most powerful ways to connect with its storied past and electric present.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
While many cities can lay claim to being hubs of musical creativity, only a few become truly synonymous with a certain sound. After all, Vienna will always waltz to the tune of Strauss and few can imagine Seville without the passion of flamenco. In some cases, a city is its music. And, like that of a gifted composer, the European repertoire is vast. Whether for pop or classical, folk or techno, travellers will find no short‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: Search for food puts lives on the line
entry.summary: The worsening humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip has reached ‚Äúunprecedented levels of despair,‚Äù the UN said on Monday, amid more reports of people being killed and injured near newly-established distribution sites.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: No green without blue: Young ocean explorers set sail for a sustainable future
entry.summary: With science at the forefront of the opening day of the Third UN Ocean Conference (UNOC3), UN News boarded a 111-year-old Norwegian tall ship on the French Riviera to meet 50 science students, along with a host of lecturers and citizen scientists fresh from a 46-day expedition. Fueled by satellite data from the European Space Agency (ESA), their invaluable observations echo the urgent call to understand and protect the world‚Äôs oceans.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Lack of cooperation from Iran hampers nuclear checks, says atomic energy watchdog
entry.summary: The head of the UN-backed nuclear watchdog has raised fresh concerns over Iran‚Äôs failure to fully cooperate with inspections, warning that this is preventing independent verification of its nuclear activities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Central Africa at a crossroads amid rising tensions and instability
entry.summary: Despite its wealth of natural resources and potential, Central Africa continues to face serious challenges, from political instability to growing humanitarian needs.

entry.title: Drifting architects: Plankton, climate, and the race to understand our changing ocean
entry.summary: They drift unseen, but everything depends on them. Plankton ‚Äì the ocean‚Äôs lifeblood ‚Äì¬†regulate the climate, feed the seas, and shape life on Earth. On the French Riviera, scientists are racing to unlock their secrets before the hush of their decline echoes across the planet.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Women and girls struggle to manage their periods amid crisis
entry.summary: Whether it‚Äôs their first time or a routine part of their life, menstruation has become a nightmare for women and girls in Gaza. The conditions they are forced to endure - displacement, overcrowded shelters, and lack of basic hygiene - have turned a natural biological process into a monthly ordeal.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Love Moroccan architecture? Try this city instead of Marrakech
entry.summary:
You can organise a guided tour of the Hassan II Mosque with Casam√©moire, a non-profit that‚Äôs been working to preserve the city‚Äôs 20th-century architecture since 1995. Located on the Atlantic coast of Morocco, the nation‚Äôs most populous city is a layer cake of soaring mosques, art deco cinemas and technicolour murals.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Casablanca is well versed in transformation. Anfa, the Amazigh settlement that once stood here, was obliterated by the Portuguese in 1468. When they returned to rebuild the town half a century later, they renamed it ‚ÄòCasa Branca‚Äô (White House). An earthquake then levelled the region in 1755, prompting Moroccan ruler Sultan Mohammed ben Abdallah to build the whitewashed Medina. Earning itself the lo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Stigmatised for being deaf: Z√©nabou's Story
entry.summary: In the Central African Republic, disability carries¬†a deep-rooted stigma, and persons with disabilities often find themselves excluded from almost every avenue of life. Z√©nabou, who is deaf and non-speaking, has suffered from prejudice, but a UN-backed educational programme offers a glimmer of hope.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Chengdu's ancient teahouses are going viral‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs barely 9am when I slide into a bamboo armchair at Heming Tea House in Chengdu‚Äôs sprawling People‚Äôs Park. This century-old stalwart is one of the oldest teahouses in the megacity that I called home until I was nine. While I was growing up here, in one of China‚Äôs oldest tea-growing areas, many weekends were spent in an open-air teahouse like this one.
While adults played games of mahjong and the kids ran riot, roving hawkers carrying heavy baskets balanced on bamboo shoulder poles would come round selling snacks. The most famous of these is dan dan mian (shoulder pole noodles), where a nest of cold noodles is placed on a hot and tongue-numbing mala chilli oil base, topped with spring onion and minced meat, then‚Ä¶

entry.title: 9 Rome restaurants locals swear by
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In Rome, where every other restaurant promises a ‚Äòtrue‚Äô carbonara or ‚Äòclassic‚Äô pizza, the pursuit of authenticity can feel elusive. Travellers often stay within the confines of the historical centre and rely on the greatest hits served in well-worn trattorias offering English-language menus. But do as the locals do and seek out culinary quality in Rome‚Äôs quieter corners and you‚Äôll really get a flavour of the city. From contemporary trattorias to wine kiosks, here are nine of the best places to eat in Rome ‚Äî trusted spots that locals return to time after time. Duck rag√π clings to strands of chitarra pasta in this deeply flavourful primo at Santo Palato. Santo Palato‚Äôs tiramisu comes unapologetically tall, with ge‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 places where you can ditch your car this summer
entry.summary:
Pedestrians stroll through the old town in H·ªôi An, Vietnam. A river trading port from the 15th through 19th centuries, it‚Äôs one of many destinations around the globe that ban or severely limit cars. You can walk, hike, and bike‚Äîbut not drive‚Äîthrough these destinations that prohibit automobiles.
More than¬†45 million U.S. travelers¬†took road trips for Memorial Day 2025‚Äîan increase of approximately one million from the previous year, breaking the 2005 record of 44 million people driving to their desired destination for the holiday weekend.
Choosing a car-free destination is a way both to save at the pump and help save the planet. Places that prohibit, or at least greatly restrict, motorized vehicles range from the well-known (Venice, Italy, the world‚Äôs largest pedestrian zone), t‚Ä¶

entry.title: The butterfly effect is a real phenomenon‚Äîbut not how you think
entry.summary:
In 1961, MIT meteorologist Edward Lorenz was inputting numbers into a weather prediction program. His model was based on a dozen variables, the value of one being .506127. When he ran the model again, he rounded that number to .506, then left the room to grab a coffee. When he came back, he discovered this tiny change had resulted in a dramatically different weather prediction.
When presenting his resultant groundbreaking model of chaos and the potential of extreme chaotic unpredictability at the 1972 meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), Lorenz posed the question: ‚ÄúDoes the flap of a butterfly‚Äôs wings in Brazil set off a tornado in Texas?‚Äù¬†

entry.title: Take a solo trip to the honeymoon capital of the world
entry.summary:
After two overnight flights and a brief stop in Istanbul, I found myself island-hopping alone through the Maldives on a tiny seaplane surrounded by couples. I was the last stop: Velaa Private Island‚Äîa palm-studded speck of sand in the middle of the impossibly blue Indian Ocean. The Maldives is often associated with honeymoons and vacations for couples, but it is a destination for everyone. Some of the villas are accessible only by boat. There are certain destinations that seem made for couples. Paris is one that lives large in our imaginations, conjuring images of strolling hand in hand along the Seine. The Maldives is another, with white sand beaches, luxury resorts, and overwater bungalows that are almost synonymous with the word ‚Äúhoneymoon."
I always thought the M‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can hypnosis really treat hot flashes?
entry.summary:
The use of hypnosis for medical and psychological purposes dates back centuries. In the 18th century, Austrian physician Franz Anton Mesmer believed ‚Äúmesmerism‚Äù to be caused by an invisible fluid between the subject and the therapist. The practice was used to alter the perception of pain in surgical patients, and help people with psychological issues.
Today hypnosis is understood to be a subjective state in which perception or memory can be evoked by suggestion. While our understanding of hypnotism has evolved, the practice is still a useful tool for both medicine and psychology. Modern day hypnotism has been used in battling addiction, provide relief from chronic pain, and most recently reducing the occurrence of hot flashes.¬†

entry.title: 7 places around the world that honor LGBTQ+ history
entry.summary:
Qtopia Sydney‚Äîonce the Darlinghurst Police Station‚Äîis a museum and cultural center for queer history and culture. It features 18 exhibitions, spanning five major themes: HIV/AIDS, human rights, sexuality and identity, media representation, and First Nations stories. From Florida to Germany, these institutions are dedicated to preserving and celebrating queer history, art, and culture year-round.
Curious travelers seeking to understand different cultures‚Äînear and abroad‚Äîcan cure their curiosity by visiting historic landmarks and museums. The same can be done when expanding one's knowledge about the LGBTQ+ community and its history‚Äîand not just during Pride month in June. These places are open to the public year-round and collect, preserve, and share untold LGBTQ+ stories and contrib‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòMake-or-Break Moment‚Äô: Wahyu Dhyatmika on the Growing Threats Confronting Independent Journalism in Indonesia
entry.summary: For veteran journalist Wahyu Dhyatmika, Indonesia's intensely challenging press climate is a wake-up call for the media to retool its business model and refocus on serving the public.

entry.title: Koala moms make their kids eat poo. It‚Äôs for their own good.
entry.summary:
When it‚Äôs time to feed the kids, koala moms do their doody. Then the little ones snack on it.
Before you poo-poo the idea, a koala mom feeding¬†a form of¬†excrement to their young is a life-saving precaution called papping.¬†
‚ÄúPap is a¬†different type of feces¬†than their normal feces,‚Äù says¬†Sally Bornbusch, a research associate at the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. Adult koalas eat only eucalyptus leaves, which are toxic to most animals‚Äîand baby koalas, aka joeys, can‚Äôt digest them yet.¬†
When they‚Äôre born, koalas are less than an inch long, and they look more like a gummy bear than a koala bear. They make their way from the birth canal to mom‚Äôs pouch, where they will stay and nurse for about seven months.¬†

entry.title: The surprisingly relatable reason why some birds get cranky
entry.summary:
Some bird species, like the European robin seen here, act more aggressively when living in city environments. A new study shows that one group of Gal√°pagos yellow warblers responds to intruders more aggressively than others. It adds compelling new evidence to a theory about angry birds.
Trafficked roads, loud noises,¬†suffocating smog. For some people, living in the city can be stressful and unnerving. But a growing body of research shows some city birds can be more aggressive than their rural counterparts, suggesting they too feel the pressures of city life.
In a study published in April in the journal Animal Behavior, researchers showed that Gal√°pagos yellow warblers that live near trafficked roads in the Ecuadorian archipelago respond to intruders more aggressively than tho‚Ä¶

entry.title: A new blood test can tell if cancer has returned
entry.summary:
New blood tests can detect cancer recurrence earlier than traditional scans, potentially giving doctors and patients crucial information to make decisions about treatment. But more studies are needed to determine whether these detections change survival rates.  But whether patients should be getting the tests‚Äîas some already are‚Äîis not yet clear.
When Jennifer Feenstra was diagnosed with advanced, aggressive lung cancer five years ago, she didn‚Äôt waste time fretting about how she, a non-smoking fitness buff, could have gotten the disease. Instead, the 59-year-old retired graphic designer from Stamford, Connecticut, was determined to throw everything at it.
After surgeons at the Yale Cancer Center removed part of her right lung, she endured four rounds of gruelin‚Ä¶

entry.title: See France's Basque coast through the eyes of a photographer
entry.summary:
The harbour at St-Jean-de-Luz offers a view to Ciboure, south of Biarritz, where the town and its neighbours retain a nostalgic charm. The pearl of France‚Äôs Basque coast, Biarritz has long been a playground for European high society. Today, the town and its neighbours retain a nostalgic charm, with visitors drawn to the region for fine dining, belle epoque architecture and surf breaks.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). The couple‚Äôs summertime sojourns made the belle √©poque-era seaside town popular with European royalty. But crowns and tiaras could not outshine the land‚Äôs unique Basque heritage, evident in its language, artistic expression and food culture. Basque cuisine remains popular to this day, from the traditional bakeries that‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòUnstable‚Äô asteroids lurk around Venus‚Äîis Earth at risk?
entry.summary:
Venus has groupies‚Äîa family of asteroids that share its orbit, either trailing it or leading it as the planet revolves around the sun. Researchers have known that such stealthy space rocks might exist for years, but now, a pair of papers (one published in a journal, and one a pre-print undergoing peer-review) conclude that some might develop unstable orbits and, over a very long period of time, arch toward Earth.
But despite what several histrionic headlines have claimed, Earth is not at risk of one of these asteroids suddenly sneaking up on us and vaporizing a city. While some of these asteroids could be large enough to cause this sort of damage, there is no evidence whatsoever suggesting any of these Venus-pursuing asteroids are currently heading our way.¬†
‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say that ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 169 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 28 to May 4, 2025. A total of 5,085 panelists responded out of 5,772 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Americans‚Äô interest in purchasing electric and hybrid vehicles
entry.summary: The electric vehicle market in the U.S. continues to expand, albeit at a slower pace than earlier in the decade. One-third of Americans say they would very or somewhat seriously consider purchasing an electric vehicle (EV) as their next vehicle. This is a slight uptick from last year (4 percentage points), but still down from [‚Ä¶] The post 2. Americans‚Äô interest in purchasing electric and hybrid vehicles appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views on Trump administration energy policies and priorities
entry.summary: The Trump administration has taken a number of actions to promote the development and use of fossil fuels and reduce support for renewable energy. This includes a push to increase drilling for oil and natural gas on federal lands and an executive order pausing approvals and permits for wind energy projects, including offshore wind. Where [‚Ä¶] The post 1. Views on Trump administration energy policies and priorities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans‚Äô Views on Energy at the Start of Trump‚Äôs Second Term
entry.summary: Americans have become less supportive of wind and solar power since the first Trump administration, a shift driven by declines in support among Republicans. The post Americans‚Äô Views on Energy at the Start of Trump‚Äôs Second Term appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: AIDS still killing one person every minute as funding cuts stall progress
entry.summary: AIDS-related deaths have dropped to their lowest level since 2004, but progress remains precarious, with the disease still claiming one life every minute. The impact of funding cuts is severe, causing widespread disruption to HIV services and threatening hard-won gains.

entry.summary: As hostilities rage in Sudan, access constraints and devastating funding cuts are isolating rape survivors and pregnant women from essential health services, the UN sexual and reproductive health agency UNFPA said on Thursday.

entry.title: Number of aid workers killed in Gaza conflict, highest in UN history: Guterres
entry.summary: The United Nations paid tribute on Thursday to the 168 staff members who lost their lives in 2024. They include 126 personnel killed in Gaza, all but one of whom served with the UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA.
